head.title: Schooner Nancy, Log and Lists of Provisions, 1811-1813. - Page #22

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #22 of 71 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Mackintosh, Alexander. Schooner Nancy, Log and Lists of Provisions, 1811-1813. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0039

div.p: Remarks & occurrences on board the Nancy hired Transport on her return passage to either Makinac or St Josephs in the month of October 1813[.]

First part of this 24 hours showery, & light breez[e] of wind at South, but not sufficiently strong to stem the rappid, at day light call'd all hands, hove up, & made sail, moderate breezes from the southwards – hung the boat in the tackles, at about 8 AM enter the lake after being about ¾ of an hour in the rappid – we then fired 3 guns & cheered 3 times – made sail & hove up for the anchor which we left behind on our passage downwards – succeeded in recovering it, made all secure on deck, & stowed the holds – at noon fresh breezes from the WSW, occasionally took in top gallant sails as required course N by W½W keeping close in with the land fearing the wind to head, at 4 PM bent the small bower again at ½ past 5 squally from the WSW, took a reef in each of the top sails, & set top gallant sails over, the point of Bark distant about 8 miles Course NNW at 6 all sail set fresh breezes, & cloudy weather, at 8 took in top gallant sails & flying jibb ½ book in, at 11 handed the square sail, & single reefed the main sail wind encreases to a gale from WNW, showery[.]

[A]bout 4 AM Jonas & Jacob having the morning watch (for I had doubled the anchor watch), Jonas called Jacob who refused to turn out saying "he be damned, that he already had a watch & would not go – this I heard whilst in my bed for I did not sleep a wink all night but turned in all standing ready at a moments call[.]

First part of this 24 hours still continues to blow fresh from the same quarter, at 6 AM close reefed the fore top sail, & handed the main one & bore ship to the Westward wind NW by W at 11 wind WSW wore ship to the Northward at 2 PM a heavy squall from the WNW with hail, settled the fore top sail on the cap, at 4 wind NW & blows harder than at any time, handed the fore top sail wore ship to the Westward, rolling gunnel in, handed the fore sail, last part of this day wind stands from NW to WNW[.]

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
